Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal entry or re-entry into Canada
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a deportation order be quashed after the underlying conviction is overturned?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was deported based on a valid conviction; later acquitted but delayed filing for judicial review
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and extension of time to file
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Application dismissed due to unjustified delay
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Failed to file judicial review within statutory period
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Deportation orders valid if based on lawful conviction at time of issuance
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Late filing of judicial review application
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record, acquittal document, filing dates
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA provisions on deportation and judicial review timelines
Crimes.Application_Basis: Challenge to deportation based on post-conviction developments
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Timing and justification for delay in legal challenge
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Deportation orders remain valid despite subsequent acquittal if lawful when issued
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of justification for delay in filing
Crimes.Cause_Description: Conviction for mischief led to deportation; later acquittal prompted challenge
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed timeline and legal validity of order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: None â€” compliance with IRPA procedures affirmed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA Section on Deportation Orders and Judicial Review
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Focus on procedural timeliness rather than factual guilt
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Order was lawful when made; no retroactive invalidation upon acquittal
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to provide adequate explanation for delay
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Standard for granting extension of time for judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a deportation order be quashed due to the subsequent acquittal of the applicant, or does the time limit for judicial review prevent such action?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted, then acquitted; filed judicial review after 15-day deadline
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Extension of time and judicial review
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Delayed legal challenge without sufficient reason
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Validity of deportation order assessed at time of issuance
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Justification for delay in filing beyond statutory period
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for extension of time to file judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Court records of conviction and acquittal, filing dates
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA sections relating to inadmissibility and appeal rights
Crimes.Application_Basis: Post-acquittal challenge to deportation grounded in prior conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Temporal gap between acquittal and filing of review
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn deportation order based on invalidated conviction
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Orders valid when made remain enforceable absent procedural illegality
Crimes.Cause_Description: Conviction triggered deportation; acquittal formed basis for challenge
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Emphasis on procedural adherence over substantive outcome change
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on criminal inadmissibility and judicial review
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Timeliness outweighed merits in procedural evaluation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No retroactive effect of acquittal on lawfully issued deportation order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to justify delay constitutes procedural bar
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Test for extending time limits under federal rules

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a deportation order be quashed due to the subsequent acquittal of the applicant, rendering the original conviction void?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of conviction validity and timing of legal challenges
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to justify delay and demonstrate error
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Deportation orders based on lawful convictions stand even if conviction later overturned
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness of administrative decision and timeliness of challenge
Crimes.Review_Standard: Whether decision was reasonable and within legal framework
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Process followed required timelines and notice
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Original conviction, acquittal, date of filing for review
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Interplay between criminal law and immigration consequences
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Argued that deportation should not stand after acquittal
Crimes.Legal_Rule_Source: IRPA and case law on finality of administrative decisions
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities for extension requests
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Did not contest facts but challenged immigration consequence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and quashing of deportation order
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA on inadmissibility due to criminality
Crimes.Authority: Canada Border Services Agency and Immigration Division
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Individual with prior criminal charge affecting immigration status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 36(1), related to criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Administrative decisions based on valid legal grounds at time of issue are not undone by later events unless specifically allowed
